choices.text: Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle
Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck
The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle
The movement by which the head is born

questions.text: What is restitution? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head rotating due to untwisting of the neck

 

Restitution is one of the cardinal movements of labor that occurs after the delivery of the fetal head. During internal rotation, the fetal neck gets twisted by 45 degrees (for example, in Left Occipital Anterior position). Once the head is delivered and free from the bony confines of the pelvis, it naturally untwists to align with the fetal body. This untwisting movement of the head is called restitution.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head rotated by 1/8th of a circle: Incorrect. Restitution isn't defined by the degree of rotation (though a 45-degree rotation is approximately 1/8th of a circle). Rather, restitution specifically refers to the untwisting mechanism and its purpose.

 

Option C. The shoulder undergoing rotation by 1/8th of circle: Incorrect. Shoulder rotation occurs after restitution and is part of a different cardinal step called external rotation. During external rotation, the shoulders enter the pelvis and undergo internal rotation, which manifests as the head rotating externally.

 

Option D. The movement by which the head is born: Incorrect. This describes extension, which is the movement that occurs when the head is being delivered, before restitution takes place.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Restitution is the untwisting movement of the fetal head that occurs after delivery of the head, correcting the twist that occurred during internal rotation.

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly seen on the ultrasound. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows a characteristic "frog face" appearance, which is highly indicative of anencephaly. Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This condition can be identified as early as 12 to 14 weeks of gestation via ultrasound. The typical appearance on the ultrasound includes the absence of the cranial vault and cerebral hemispheres, resulting in the recognizable frog-like appearance of the fetus’s head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Encephalocele: This is incorrect. Encephalocele is a neural tube defect characterized by a sac-like protrusion of the brain and membranes through an opening in the skull. It does not present with the “frog face” appearance.

 

Option C. Lissencephaly: This is incorrect. Lissencephaly is a brain malformation characterized by the absence of normal brain folds (gyri) and is not associated with the absence of the skull or the typical features seen in the image.

 

Option D. Holoprosencephaly: This is incorrect. Holoprosencephaly involves the failure of the brain to divide into two hemispheres and has a different ultrasound appearance, often showing facial anomalies like a single eye or cleft palate, but not the frog-like appearance seen in anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly presents on ultrasound with a distinct "frog face" appearance due to the absence of the cranial vault and cerebral hemispheres. It can be diagnosed early in pregnancy, typically around 12 to 14 weeks.

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which step is not included in active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bimanual compression

 

Active Management of Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) consists of three basic components as defined by WHO in the early 2000s:

 

  1. Administration of oxytocics (primarily oxytocin)
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
  3. Uterine massage (now termed as postpartum vigilance)

 

An additional component that has been recently added is delayed cord clamping, though this is primarily for preventing neonatal anemia rather than preventing postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine massage: Uterine massage is a core component of AMTSL. While the terminology has evolved to "postpartum vigilance," it remains an essential step where the uterus is checked and massaged if not well contracted.

 

Option C. CCT (Controlled Cord Traction): CCT is one of the three basic steps of AMTSL.

 

Option D. Administration of oxytocics: Administration of oxytocics, particularly oxytocin, is the first and crucial step of AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bimanual compression is a treatment method for atonic postpartum hemorrhage, not a preventive measure in AMTSL. The three basic components of AMTSL are: administration of oxytocics, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage/postpartum vigilance.

questions.text: A 24-year-old P1L1 woman presented with acute abdominal pain. She has a H/O RHD and recently went for mitral valve replacement and is currently on warfarin therapy. On examination, there is a 14-week size abdominal pelvic mass and on USG, a 6 × 8 cm unilocular cyst with reticular appearance is seen. What is the next best step in management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical exploration

 

In this case, surgical exploration is the best next step because:

 

  • The patient has a large (6×8 cm) symptomatic ovarian cyst with reticular appearance suggesting hemorrhage
  • The hemorrhagic nature is likely due to warfarin therapy
  • Due to the large size and symptoms (acute abdominal pain), conservative management is not appropriate
  • However, before surgery: 
    • Anticoagulation needs to be stopped
    • INR needs to be corrected (may require vitamin K)
    • Patient may need bridging with heparin
    • Surgery should be performed only after coagulation parameters are normalized

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MRI:

 

  • Not necessary as USG has already provided clear visualization of the cyst
  • Won't add significant diagnostic value given the clear hemorrhagic appearance on USG

 

Option C. Follow up:

 

  • Not appropriate for a large (6*8 cm) symptomatic cyst
  • Conservative management is suitable for smaller, asymptomatic cysts
  • Risk of continued hemorrhage due to anticoagulation

 

Option D. Measure Ca-125:

 

  • Not indicated as the imaging characteristics suggest a benign hemorrhagic cyst
  • Patient is young and USG findings are not suspicious for malignancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large hemorrhagic ovarian cysts in patients on anticoagulation require surgical management after correcting coagulation parameters.

choices.text: Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation
All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight
Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation
All term babies irrespective of birth weight

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping done? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation

 

According to WHO guidelines, delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies who do not require resuscitation. This practice has been incorporated into the active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL) protocol. The primary benefit is the prevention of neonatal anemia, with particular effectiveness in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation: Incorrect because it excludes preterm babies, who benefit more from delayed cord clamping

 

Option B. All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes preterm babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Option D. All term babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation, with the only contraindication being the need for immediate resuscitation in an asphyxiated baby.

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vagina mixed with mucous discharge. On examination, a necrotizing growth is seen in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. What will be the management for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemoradiation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a foul-smelling bloody discharge mixed with mucous discharge, and a necrotizing growth in the cervix with lateral parametrium involvement. These clinical features are suggestive of advanced cervical cancer. The involvement of the lateral parametrium indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the cervix to the surrounding tissues but not to the pelvic wall or the lower third of the vagina, which classifies it as Stage 2B cervical cancer. The standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer is chemoradiation, which combines chemotherapy with radiation therapy. This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of the treatment, reduce tumor size, and prevent further spread of the cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the standard treatment for Stage 2B cervical cancer. It may be used in conjunction with radiation, but not as a sole therapy in this stage.

 

Option B. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy, a form of internal radiation therapy, is typically used for early-stage cervical cancer or in combination with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced stages. However, it is not sufficient as a standalone treatment for Stage 2B.

 

Option D. Surgery: Surgery is generally not recommended for Stage 2B cervical cancer due to the extent of the disease spread to the parametrium. The preferred approach is chemoradiation to address both local and regional disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 2B cervical cancer, characterized by lateral parametrium involvement, is best managed with chemoradiation.

 

Staging of CA Cervix

 

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Surgery: for early stages like stage 1, stage 2A1
  • Radiotherapy: for all patients from Stage 1 to 4

 

 

Chemoradiation can be offered at all stages

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: Shortest anterior posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstetric conjugate

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet through which the baby passes during delivery. It extends from the sacral promontory to a point on the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. This is the clinically significant diameter as it represents the actual space available for fetal descent.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anatomical conjugate (also called true conjugate): This extends from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. While it is a pelvic measurement, it has no clinical significance.

 

Option B. Diagonal conjugate: This is measured during pelvic examination from the sacral promontory to the lower border of pubic symphysis. When 1.5 cm is subtracted from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

 Option D. True conjugate: This is the same as the anatomical conjugate, extending from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. It has no clinical significance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest and most clinically significant anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet, measuring from the sacral promontory to the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. The diagonal conjugate can be measured clinically, and subtracting 1.5 cm from it gives the obstetric conjugate.

choices.text: Remove placenta and reposition the uterus
Put uterus inside without removing the placenta
Shift to OT and insert the uterus back

questions.text: A patient has just delivered a full-term baby and developed uterine inversion with the placenta still attached. What is the immediate next step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Put uterus inside without removing the placenta

 

Immediate management of uterine inversion involves repositioning the uterus before removing the placenta to prevent severe bleeding and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to massive hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Shift to OT and insert the uterus back: Immediate manual repositioning is crucial before shifting to an operating theatre.

 

Option D. Start Oxytocin: Oxytocin is used after the uterus is repositioned to encourage contraction, not before.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of uterine inversion, the uterus should be repositioned with the placenta still attached to avoid significant bleeding, followed by medical management for uterine contraction.

questions.text: IUCD can be inserted after delivery till? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 48hrs


An Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD), specifically the Copper T, can be inserted immediately after delivery as part of postpartum family planning. The optimal time frames for insertion include:

 

  1. Post-placental insertion: Within 10 minutes of placental delivery, commonly done when the patient is highly motivated.
  2. Early postpartum insertion: From 10 minutes up to 48 hours after delivery.
  3. Intra-caesarean insertion: At the time of cesarean section.
  4. Late postpartum – After 6 weeks 

 

Early postpartum IUCD insertion is considered safe and effective during this period due to the lower risk of expulsion and higher motivation of the patient.

 

Note -  48hrs to 6 weeks’ period is not suitable for IUCD insertion due to the high risk of expulsion and complications as the uterus is actively involuting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD can be inserted within 48 hours of delivery, but not between 48 hours to 6 weeks due to the high risk of expulsion during this time.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: 15-year-old girl with wide-spaced nipples, short height, and the following karyotype: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome


Turner syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45, X) rather than the typical two sex chromosomes (XX or XY). The karyotype shown confirms the absence of the Y chromosome and only one X chromosome, which is diagnostic of Turner syndrome. Clinical features often include short stature, wide-spaced nipples, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. Turner syndrome is a common genetic condition tested in exams due to its distinctive features and significant clinical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It does not fit the description of a 15-year-old girl with the specific karyotype shown and is not associated with the physical characteristics described.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra chromosome 21) and typically presents with distinct facial features, intellectual disability, and other health issues. The karyotype shown does not match Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Partial mole: A partial mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease involving an abnormal pregnancy with an extra set of paternal chromosomes, often presenting with symptoms related to pregnancy and abnormal placental tissue rather than the clinical features described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45,X, and typical clinical features include short stature and wide-spaced nipples, commonly seen in females.

choices.text: Increase SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

questions.text: Physiological changes in pregnancy include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in SBP and DBP at 6 weeks

 

During pregnancy, blood pressure decreases throughout pregnancy, with the maximum fall occurring in the second trimester. This is a normal physiological adaptation. An increase in blood pressure (either systolic or diastolic) is not a normal physiological change and could indicate a pathological condition like preeclampsia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Fasting Hypoglycemia and Postprandial Hyperglycemia: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change in pregnancy. Pregnant women experience fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia as part of normal pregnancy adaptation.

 

Option C. Increase in RBC mass: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. During pregnancy, there is an increase in RBC mass, although the increase in plasma volume is proportionally greater, leading to physiological anemia.

 

Option D. Peripheral Insulin Resistance: This is incorrect as this is a normal physiological change. Pregnancy is characterized by increased peripheral insulin resistance, which puts women at higher risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective: 


Blood pressure normally decreases during pregnancy, with maximum fall in the second trimester. Any increase in blood pressure during pregnancy is abnormal and requires evaluation.

questions.text: The type of pelvis commonly associated with occipitoposterior and face to pubis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 

 

 

The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by a larger anteroposterior diameter compared to its transverse diameter, giving it a vertical oval shape. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern, where the baby's face presents toward the pubic symphysis during delivery. The anthropoid shape often causes the baby's head to rotate into a posterior position, leading to a higher likelihood of occipitoposterior presentations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynecoid pelvis: The gynecoid pelvis is the typical female pelvis with a round shape and balanced anteroposterior and transverse diameters. It is most favorable for vaginal deliveries and is not commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions.

 

Option B. Android pelvis: The android pelvis is heart-shaped, narrower, and typically has prominent ischial spines. It is more commonly associated with obstructed labor and deep transverse arrest rather than occipitoposterior or face to pubis presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid pelvis: The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a very wide transverse diameter and a flat shape, which often leads to delayed engagement of the fetal head. It is not associated with occipitoposterior positions but can lead to asynclitism and face presentations.

 

Educational Objective:


The anthropoid pelvis is the pelvic type most commonly associated with occipitoposterior positions and the "face to pubis" delivery pattern.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant G3P2L2 woman presented to OBG department at 36 weeks of amenorrhea. Ultrasound shows that the fetus is in a transverse lie. The liquor is adequate, the placenta is normal, and she has no gross anomaly. Both her previous deliveries were normal vaginal deliveries. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External cephalic version

 

In this situation, external cephalic version should be attempted.

 

Management of Transverse lie –

 

 

Absolute Contraindications of ECV:

 

  • Placenta Previa
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Multiple Pregnancy
  • Hyperextended head
  • Uterine Anomaly
  • Dead fetus
  • Distressed fetus
  • Denied consent

 

Complications of ECV:

 

  • Abruption
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Preterm labour.
  • Fetal distress.
  • Cord presentation or prolapse
  • Entangling of the cord around the fetus.
  • Isoimmunization in Rh-negative mothers due to feto-maternal transfusion.
  • Induction of labor is contraindicated in Transverse lie.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean section: While a cesarean section is the best and safest method of delivery in cases of persistent transverse or oblique lie, it is not the first-line management in this situation where ECV can be attempted.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Waiting for spontaneous correction is not recommended at 36 weeks with a transverse lie, as it may not occur, and could lead to complications.

 

Option D. Induction of labor: Inducing labor in a transverse lie position is contraindicated as it can lead to complications such as cord prolapse and obstructed labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External cephalic version should be attempted between 36 and 37 weeks of gestation for a fetus in a transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second pregnancy is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 30 weeks gestation. What is the drug of choice for her treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is the preferred treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during pregnancy due to its safety profile and ease of monitoring. LMWH does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus compared to other anticoagulants. Additionally, LMWH requires less frequent monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin, making it more convenient for both patients and healthcare providers during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can lead to fetal complications, including congenital malformations and bleeding. Warfarin is generally reserved for patients with specific conditions such as mechanical heart valves who were already on the drug before pregnancy, under careful supervision.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: While Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant, it is not the first-line choice for DVT in pregnancy. It is generally considered when LMWH is contraindicated, such as in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Apixaban: Apixaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), is not recommended in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. DOACs are generally avoided during pregnancy because they can cross the placenta and pose risks to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, the drug of choice for treating DVT is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) due to its safety and ease of monitoring compared to other anticoagulants

questions.text:
A couple has been attempting to conceive for the past two years with unprotected intercourse yet without success, the husband's semen analysis was ordered and results are as follows: 

 

  • Volume: 2ml
  • Viability: 75%
  • Sperm count: 40 million per ejaculate

 

The wife’s HSG report shows no abnormalities. What percentage of infertile women have unexplained infertility? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15%

 

In cases of infertility, the distribution of causes follows a specific pattern:

 

  • Female factor infertility: 40%
  • Male factor infertility: 30%
  • Combined male and female factors: 15%
  • Unexplained infertility: 15%

 

Unexplained infertility is diagnosed when:

 

  • Standard fertility tests are normal
  • No obvious cause is identified despite thorough evaluation
  • Tests showing normal results include: 
    • Ovulation tests
    • Tubal patency (HSG)
    • Uterine cavity evaluation
    • Semen analysis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Unexplained infertility accounts for 15% of all infertility cases, while female factor accounts for 40%, male factor for 30%, and combined factors for 15%.

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks, especially in cases of substantial fetal anomalies, a medical board is constituted. This board typically includes specialists relevant to the condition and the required medical care. The standard members include: Radiologist, Gynecologist and Pediatrician.

 

A legal advisor is not a part of this medical board, as the board's purpose is to provide medical, not legal, expertise. The fourth member is often a specialist relevant to the detected anomaly rather than a legal professional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiologist: Included to assess fetal abnormalities through imaging and provide critical information about the anomaly.

 

Option B. Gynecologist: A core member who handles the MTP procedure and provides obstetric and gynecological care.

 

Option D. Pediatrician: Included to give an opinion on the implications of fetal anomalies and expected postnatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

questions.text: Mitochondria of spermatozoa form the: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle piece


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece of the sperm. The middle piece contains numerous mitochondria arranged in a helical pattern around the axoneme. These mitochondria are essential for providing the energy required for sperm motility through ATP production.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Head sheath: Incorrect because the head contains the nucleus and acrosome, not mitochondria 

 

Option B. Connecting part: Incorrect as it's just a transitional region 

 

Option D. Tail: Incorrect as the tail (principal piece and end piece) contains the axoneme and outer dense fibers but no mitochondria

 

Educational Objective: 


The mitochondria of spermatozoa are specifically located in the middle piece, providing energy for sperm motility.

choices.text: Genital Tuberculosis

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, difficulty in walking and sitting. She has a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, a tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bartholin abscess

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and image points to the diagnosis of Bartholin's abscess.

 

Bartholin Cyst and Abscess

 

Bartholin gland is a mucus-secreting gland, which plays a role in vaginal lubrication. They are a pair of 0.5 cm glands located in the lower right and left portions at the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal introitus. They are generally nonpalpable when not obstructed.

 

Pathophysiology: Bartholin glands can form a cyst and an abscess in women of reproductive age and may cause dyspareunia, urinary irritation, and vague pelvic pain.

 

C/F:

 

  • The physical exam will often reveal asymmetry with a protrusion of one side (left or right) of the inferior aspect of the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland abscesses, unlike Bartholin cysts, are very painful.
  • While both are primarily unilateral, Bartholin abscesses are often tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, and may have an area of fluctuance and/or purulent drainage.
  • Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Bartholin cysts do not require further treatment.
  • Bartholin abscesses may be treated with incision and drainage with Word catheter placement due to ease and effectiveness of treatment.
  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice.
  • Women with recurrent cysts or those who are post-menopausal (risk of malignancy) should have the cyst completely excised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Chlamydial infection: Chlamydial infection patient usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, or cervicitis.

 

Option C. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis involves the upper genital tract, leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Genital herpes usually presents as painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital area, rather than a tender, erythematous swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin abscess presents with significant pain, redness, and swelling in the labia, often making walking and sitting difficult.

choices.text: Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS
Start Antihypertensives and ARM

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

questions.text: Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Before 34 weeks

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that develops before 34 weeks of gestation. 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia:

 

  • Indicates potentially higher severity
  • Is associated with conditions like antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Can be prevented by administering low-dose aspirin

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before 34 weeks of gestation, while late-onset pre-eclampsia occurs after 34 weeks.

questions.text: Twin pregnancy where 1 twin is older by 1 month than the other on ultrasound. What is this known as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfetation


Superfetation is the phenomenon where two ova are released in separate menstrual cycles and are fertilized at different times, leading to the conception of twins with different gestational ages. This means that one twin is conceived at a later date than the other, which can result in an observable difference in size or developmental stage on ultrasound. Although superfetation is documented in some animals, it is extremely rare and largely theoretical in humans due to the cessation of ovulation after the first conception. Nonetheless, it is the best explanation for the scenario where one twin appears to be older by a month than the other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova released in the same menstrual cycle are fertilized by separate acts of intercourse. The twins conceived have the same gestational age, although they may vary slightly in size. This phenomenon does not explain a one-month difference in age between twins.

 

Option C. Illegitimate: This term is not a medical explanation related to twin pregnancies. It refers to a non-scientific or socially defined concept and does not pertain to any biological condition involving twins.

 

Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic: This refers to twins that share both the chorion and the amniotic sac, resulting from the splitting of a single fertilized egg. These twins are identical and have the same gestational age; they do not account for any significant size or age discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Superfetation refers to a rare phenomenon where twins are conceived at different times, resulting in a significant difference in gestational ages, although it is mostly theoretical in humans.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Crowning
  2. Engagement
  3. Restitution
  4. External rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:

 

  1. Engagement: This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  2. Descent: The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  4. Internal Rotation: The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  5. Crowning: The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  6. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis.
  7. Restitution: The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  8. External Rotation: The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  9. Expulsion of the rest of the body: The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. B, A, D, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.

 

Option C. B, C, A, D: This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.

 

Option D. B, D, A, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 145

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

choices.text: Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly

questions.text: Dr. Savita is posted in a low-resource hospital setting. She explains to a patient about risk factors of cervical cancer, including HPV. Which of the following would be appropriate for cervical cancer screening? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pap smear alone every 3 yearly

 

In a low-resource hospital setting, Pap smear alone every 3 years is the most appropriate screening method for cervical cancer. The screening should begin at age 21 years (some guidelines recommend 25 years). While HPV testing has become the method of choice in many updated guidelines, in resource-limited settings, Pap smear remains the primary screening tool due to its cost-effectiveness and established infrastructure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pap smear alone every 5 yearly: Incorrect because the recommended interval for Pap smear screening is 3 years, not 5 years. Five-yearly screening is appropriate for HPV testing or co-testing.

 

Option B. Pap smear + HPV DNA every 5 yearly: Incorrect because while co-testing is an acceptable method, it increases costs and is not the method of choice in low-resource settings. This option would unnecessarily increase the financial burden.

 

Option D. Pap smear in high-risk individuals: Incorrect because cervical cancer screening should be done in all eligible women, not just high-risk individuals. Universal screening is essential for effective prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In low-resource settings, cervical cancer screening should be done using Pap smear alone every 3 years, starting from age 21 years.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman whose last delivery was 5 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea of 2 years. She does not bleed on giving estrogen and progesterone. A laparoscopy shows the following. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital TB

 

The patient presents with secondary amenorrhea for two years and does not bleed when given estrogen and progesterone, indicating that the problem lies in the endometrium. The destruction of the endometrium can occur due to two main conditions: Asherman's syndrome and genital tuberculosis.

 

  • Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions typically following a vigorous dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Genital tuberculosis, however, causes chronic endometritis, leading to the destruction of the endometrium and the absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. The laparoscopy shows whitish caseating lesions on the surface of the uterus, which are characteristic of genital tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causing pelvic pain and infertility. It does not typically result in secondary amenorrhea or the absence of bleeding on hormone administration, and it does not produce the characteristic whitish lesions seen in the laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Fibroids: Uterine fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can cause menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, and pain but do not lead to secondary amenorrhea or absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. Fibroids also do not present with caseating lesions.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that rarely affects the genital tract. It does not cause endometrial destruction, secondary amenorrhea, or the absence of withdrawal bleeding when given hormones, nor does it produce the characteristic uterine lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis can cause chronic endometritis and endometrial destruction, leading to secondary amenorrhea and absence of withdrawal bleeding on hormone administration, with characteristic whitish caseating lesions visible on laparoscopy.

choices.text: Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%
Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock
Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID
Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic

questions.text: A 26-year woman with six weeks of amenorrhea presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, light vaginal spotting and a bp of 90/ 60 mmHg.  pelvic exam reveals right adnexal tenderness. Choose the incorrect statement about this condition. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock

 

The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the triad of amenorrhea, pain, and vaginal bleeding, along with signs of shock (BP 90/60 mmHg) and adnexal tenderness. The statement about oral methotrexate is incorrect because:

 

  1. Methotrexate is given as an intramuscular injection, not orally
  2. Medical management is contraindicated in patients with shock; they require immediate surgical intervention
  3. Hemodynamic instability is an absolute contraindication to medical management

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%: Pain is indeed the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy, occurring in approximately 90% of cases. The clinical triad includes pain, amenorrhea, and vaginal bleeding.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID: PID increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy by causing salpingitis, which reduces tubal motility and can lead to implantation within the fallopian tube.

 

Option D. Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic: While progesterone levels are typically lower in ectopic pregnancy compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy, this finding is not diagnostic and is not used for clinical decision-making.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Medical management with methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy with hemodynamic instability (shock); such cases require immediate surgical intervention.

choices.text: Leave the IUCD in situ

questions.text: A 26-year-old conceives on the IUCD. Wants to continue pregnancy. Next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remove the IUCD gently

 

The Ans. is Remove the IUCD gently. When a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed if possible. Leaving the IUCD in situ is associated with risks such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and potential fetal anomalies. While removing the IUCD does carry a slightly increased risk of miscarriage, the overall benefits of removal outweigh the risks of leaving it in place. Removal should be done carefully, with appropriate counseling provided to the patient about the potential risks involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leave the IUCD in situ: Leaving the IUCD in place is not recommended as it can lead to complications like preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and other pregnancy complications. Therefore, it should be removed if the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy.

 

Option C. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): MTP is not appropriate in this scenario because the patient wishes to continue with the pregnancy. The focus should be on managing the pregnancy safely with the IUCD removed.

 

Option D. Progesterone support: Progesterone support is not indicated in this case as it does not address the main issue, which is the presence of the IUCD and its associated risks if left in place during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a pregnancy occurs with an IUCD in place and the patient wishes to continue, the IUCD should be removed gently to minimize risks associated with leaving it in situ.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

The specimen shows an ovarian mass with a tuft of hair in a cystic space, which is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma. Key points about mature cystic teratomas include:

 

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors: They contain various types of tissues derived from the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts): Typically unilocular and contain sebaceous material, hair, and sometimes other tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissues.
  • Presentation: Most patients are asymptomatic, but they may present with an abdominal mass, acute pain due to torsion of the ovary, or rarely due to rupture of the cyst.
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is the treatment of choice for mature teratomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature teratoma: These are malignant and contain immature embryonic tissues, often neuroectodermal. They usually occur in younger patients and are more aggressive.

 

Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains mucinous material and does not contain hair or other tissues.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains clear serous fluid and lacks the complex tissues found in teratomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

 

Explanation:

 

The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:

 

  • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy: COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.

 

However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.

 

Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 489

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 37 weeks. She is a known case of heart disease with a prosthetic valve on warfarin. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to LMWH

 

The patient is a 37-week pregnant woman with a known case of heart disease and a prosthetic valve, currently on warfarin. In pregnant patients with prosthetic heart valves, anticoagulation management is crucial to prevent thromboembolic complications. Warfarin is typically avoided in the late third trimester due to the risk of fetal bleeding and other complications during delivery. It is recommended to switch from warfarin to heparin (usually low molecular weight heparin, LMWH) at around 36 weeks of gestation.

 

Since the patient is still on warfarin at 37 weeks, the immediate action is to switch to LMWH to reduce the risks associated with warfarin during labor and delivery. Before planning an induction of labor (IOL) or cesarean section, heparin should be stopped 12-24 hours before the planned delivery to minimize the risk of bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin: Continuing warfarin at this stage is inappropriate because it increases the risk of bleeding for both the mother and the fetus during labor or delivery. Warfarin crosses the placenta and poses significant risks during the peripartum period.

 

Option C. Immediate cesarean: There is no immediate indication for a cesarean section based on her anticoagulation status alone. Cesarean delivery would only be indicated for obstetric reasons. Moreover, performing surgery while the patient is on warfarin increases the risk of severe bleeding complications.

 

Option D. Immediate IOL (Induction of Labor): Immediate induction of labor is not the first step as the patient is still on warfarin, which poses a bleeding risk. Before planning any delivery method, it is essential to switch to heparin and allow a safe window without anticoagulation before proceeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves on warfarin, switch to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at 36 weeks to reduce the risk of complications during delivery, and stop heparin 12-24 hours before planned delivery.

choices.text: OCP + Anti androgen
Counsel for metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is used in eclampsia management to prevent seizures. However, MgSO₄ toxicity can occur, which necessitates stopping or adjusting the dose. The first sign of MgSO₄ toxicity is the absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), followed by respiratory depression and reduced urine output. Since magnesium is excreted through the kidneys, urine output is a critical measure of magnesium toxicity risk. A urine output of less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours) indicates poor excretion and potential toxicity, requiring immediate adjustment or cessation of MgSO₄.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of a knee jerk (deep tendon reflex) is a positive sign and indicates that magnesium levels are not yet toxic. The absence of DTRs is the first indication of toxicity, so this is not a reason to stop MgSO₄.

 

Option B. RR 18/min: A respiratory rate above 10 breaths per minute is safe when on MgSO₄. Respiratory depression is a sign of advanced toxicity; therefore, a rate of 18 per minute is not concerning.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are symptoms associated with eclampsia or pre-eclampsia (e.g., retinal detachment or blurred vision) but are not signs of MgSO₄ toxicity. These do not indicate the need to stop MgSO₄.

 

Educational Objective:


MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

choices.text: Need for blood transfusion
Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS
Risk of peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.

questions.text: Identify the prolapse?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele

 

The image shows a Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele, based on the old classification system  classification). In this grading system:

 

  • Grade 1: Prolapse remains inside the vagina.
  • Grade 2: Prolapse reaches the introitus but does not protrude outside.
  • Grade 3: Prolapse extends outside the introitus but not entirely out, and can include anterior vaginal wall prolapse as seen with cystocele.
  • Grade 4 (Procedentia): The entire uterus is outside the introitus.

 

The observed prolapse primarily shows the anterior vaginal wall protruding, indicating a cystocele. A distinguishing feature between Grade 3 and Grade 4 prolapse is the thumb-finger test: if the thumb and finger can approximate over the swelling completely, it indicates Grade 4 prolapse; otherwise, it is Grade 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 3 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect because the protrusion is primarily from the anterior wall, characteristic of a cystocele, not a rectocele (posterior wall).

 

Option C. Grade 2 prolapse with cystocele: This is incorrect as Grade 2 would not extend outside the introitus, whereas the prolapse seen here is visibly beyond the introitus.

 

Option D. Grade 2 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect for the same reasons as Grade 2 cystocele; additionally, the prolapse involves the anterior wall rather than the posterior, ruling out rectocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 3 prolapse extends outside the introitus and can involve cystocele. Differentiating between Grade 3 and Grade 4 requires the thumb-finger approximation test.

questions.text: Which is not an indication of instrumental vaginal delivery? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion)

 

CPD is not an indication for instrumental delivery because when there is a disproportion between the fetal head and maternal pelvis, attempting instrumental delivery would be dangerous and ineffective. In cases of CPD, cesarean section is the appropriate mode of delivery as attempting to force the baby through an inadequate pelvis could cause trauma to both mother and baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal distress: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When there is fetal distress in the second stage of labor, expedited delivery via forceps or vacuum can help prevent adverse fetal outcomes.

 

Option C. Maternal exhaustion: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When the mother is too exhausted to effectively push, instrumental delivery can assist in the birth process.

 

Option D. Prolonged 2nd stage labour: It is a valid indication for instrumental delivery. When the second stage is prolonged (without CPD), instrumental delivery can help achieve vaginal birth and prevent complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CPD is an absolute contraindication for instrumental vaginal delivery and requires cesarean section, while fetal distress, maternal exhaustion, and prolonged second stage (without CPD) are valid indications for instrumental delivery.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.
