Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: The classification shown is for? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Pelvic organ prolapse


The classification shown in the image is the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system, which is used to classify pelvic organ prolapse.

 

Pelvic organ prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs, including the uterus, bladder, and rectum, into or outside of the vaginal canal. The POP-Q system is a standardized method that provides detailed measurements of the degree and location of prolapse using specific points and measurements.

 

The reference point in this classification is the hymen, and the system documents anterior wall descent, posterior wall descent, and other prolapse details through a 3x3 grid with six specific points (Aa, Ba, C, Ap, Bp, and D) and three measurements (genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length). This detailed system allows for accurate assessment and comparison of prolapse severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer:  is incorrect because cervical cancer staging does not use the POP-Q system. Instead, cervical cancer staging is typically done using FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) criteria, which focus on tumor size and spread rather than anatomical descent.

 

Option C. Vulvar cancer: is incorrect. Vulvar cancer staging is also not related to pelvic organ prolapse or the POP-Q classification. It typically involves examining tumor size and invasion depth.

 

Option D. Uterine anomalies: is incorrect because uterine anomalies refer to congenital abnormalities of uterine structure and do not involve prolapse quantification. These are usually diagnosed with imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, not classified with a system like POP-Q.

 

Educational Objective:


The POP-Q system is a specific and standardized classification method used to quantify and describe the extent of pelvic organ prolapse using detailed anatomical measurements. The hymen is the reference point for this classification.

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B)  MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presented with malodorous vaginal discharge and whiff test positive. What is the likely cause? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacterial vaginosis

 

The important finding in this case is the positive whiff test, which is a specific diagnostic criterion for bacterial vaginosis (BV). The whiff test, also known as the KOH test, produces a characteristic fishy or ammonia-like odor when potassium hydroxide is added to the vaginal discharge. This is one of the Amsel criteria used to diagnose BV.

 

BV diagnosis requires three out of four Amsel criteria:

 

  1. Homogeneous gray-white discharge adhering to vaginal walls
  2. Positive whiff test
  3. Vaginal pH > 4.5 (alkaline)
  4. Presence of clue cells on microscopy (vaginal epithelial cells studded with bacteria)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Incorrect because candidal infections typically present with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and do not have a positive whiff test. The discharge is usually odorless.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: Incorrect because while trichomoniasis can cause malodorous discharge, it typically presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and does not give a positive whiff test.

 

Option D. Neisseria: Incorrect because Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection typically presents with purulent discharge and does not give a positive whiff test. The discharge is often yellow-green and may be accompanied by cervical inflammation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A positive whiff test is a key diagnostic criterion for bacterial vaginosis as part of the Amsel criteria, where 3 out of 4 criteria must be present for diagnosis.

questions.text: The primary oocyte is arrested in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prophase

 

In oogenesis, the primary oocyte is arrested in prophase of meiosis I. specifically the diplotene stage. This arrest occurs before birth and continues until puberty. The primary oocytes are formed when primordial germ cells undergo mitosis. These primary oocytes then enter meiosis I but get arrested in prophase I. This arrested state continues until puberty, when hormonal changes trigger the resumption of meiosis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pachytene: This is incorrect. While pachytene is a sub-stage of prophase I, the question asks for the main phase of arrest, which is prophase.

 

Option C. Leptotene: This is incorrect. Like pachytene, leptotene is also a sub-stage of prophase I, not the main phase where arrest occurs.

 

Option D: Metaphase: The secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase 2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase of meiosis I from fetal life until puberty. This arrest is a crucial event in female reproductive development and understanding of oogenesis.

questions.text: An HPE image of the endometrium is shown. The hormone responsible for this is secreted by? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corpus luteum 

 

The image shows secretory phase endometrium, characterized by tortuous glands rather than straight tubular glands seen in proliferative phase. The secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the post-ovulatory (luteal) phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary follicle: This structure produces estrogen, not progesterone, and is present in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. It does not cause secretory changes in the endometrium.

 

Option C. Granulosa cells: While these cells are important components of follicles and contribute to hormone production, they primarily produce estrogen as part of the developing follicle, not the progesterone responsible for secretory changes.

 

Option D. Theca interna: These cells work with granulosa cells to produce estrogen during the follicular phase. They are not responsible for progesterone production that causes secretory endometrial changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.

 

Key points about PMCS:

 

  • Timing: According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Purpose: The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • Fetal Outcome: The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • Surgical Technique: A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • Location: PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSCS: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.

 

Option B. Pfannenstiel incision: This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.

 

Option D. Done in OT: PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459265/

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the outpatient department with complaints of an inability to pass urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, a bluish hue is observed in the vagina. What is the most likely cause of her condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate Hymen

 

The features in this case pointing to imperforate hymen are:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain (cryptomenorrhea)
  • Urinary retention
  • Bluish hue/bulge in vagina
  • Adolescent age group

 

The bluish hue is pathognomonic of imperforate hymen as the collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos) is visible through the thin hymenal membrane.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: While it can present similarly like imperforate hymen, a transverse vaginal septum is thicker and would not show the characteristic bluish hue. An MRI would be needed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome: This condition involves absence of uterus. There would be no menstrual blood collection and thus no cyclical pain or bluish hue, as there is no uterus to generate menstrual flow.

 

Option D. OHVIRA syndrome: This presents with normal menstruation as there is only partial obstruction of vagina (hemivagina) and uterine didelphys. Patients typically have gradually worsening dysmenorrhea and may develop endometriosis. It is associated with ipsilateral renal agenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, and urinary retention in adolescent girls. The pathognomonic finding is a bluish bulge in the vagina due to collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos).

choices.text: Do UPT and then give DMPA

questions.text: A female patient taking DMPA came 14 days late. What should be advised to her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give DMPA, no backup required

 

When a patient is up to 15 days late for a Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection, it is generally safe to administer the injection without additional contraceptive backup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do UPT and then give DMPA: Pregnancy testing is typically not required unless the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option B. DMPA + 7 days backup: Backup contraception is recommended if the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option C. DMPA from next cycle: There is no need to wait until the next cycle if the delay is within 15 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients receiving DMPA who are less than 15 days late for their injection, it can be administered without the need for additional contraceptive measures or delay.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warning bleeds

 

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, either over or close to the internal cervical os. Key features of placenta previa include:

 

  • Warning bleeds: Also known as sentinel bleeds, are sudden-onset, recurrent, painless vaginal bleeding episodes that typically begin in the third trimester or during labor.
  • Soft, non-tender uterus: The abdominal examination reveals a soft and non-tender uterus, with the fundal height proportionate to the gestational age.
  • Normal fetal heart rate: The fetal heart rate is usually normal unless there is severe bleeding due to a large separation.
  • Malpresentations are common: Due to the lower placement of the placenta.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via transabdominal sonography or transvaginal sonography, which is safe and more accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark painful bleeding: This is characteristic of placental abruption, not placenta previa. Placental abruption presents with painful, dark vaginal bleeding due to the premature separation of the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine tenderness: Uterine tenderness is also a feature of placental abruption, where the uterus becomes firm and tender due to bleeding and clot formation behind the placenta.

 

Option D. Increased large uterine size: This is not a specific feature of placenta previa. Uterine size in placenta previa is proportionate to the gestational age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa typically presents with painless, recurrent vaginal bleeding (warning bleeds) in the third trimester or during labor, with a soft, non-tender uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg1940, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 307

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete woman presents the gyne clinic with complaints of secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. She has a history of low body weight and occasional dieting to maintain her physique with a current BMI of 17.5. Laboratory investigations reveal the following hormone levels LH=0.3, FSH=2, Prolactin=20ng, TSH: 1.2, BMI: 17.5. She likely to suffer from? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

The features in this case point to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

  • Low FSH and LH levels (FSH=2, LH=0.3) - normal values are usually between 2-10
  • Athletic female with low BMI (17.5)
  • History of dieting and low body weight This condition is typically seen in athletes and women with low BMI, where reduced body fat leads to decreased production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH) by the pituitary gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary ovarian insufficiency: Incorrect because this condition presents with high FSH and LH values due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries.

 

Option C. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism: Incorrect because this presents with high, not low, gonadotropin levels.

 

Option D. Normogonadotropic normogonadism: Incorrect because the patient has low, not normal, gonadotropin levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in female athletes is characterized by:

 

  • Low FSH and LH levels (<2)
  • Associated with low BMI and excessive exercise
  • Common cause of secondary amenorrhea in athletes

questions.text: What would be the mode of delivery in images 1 and 2? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image 1: Vaginal; image 2: Cesarean

 

In the provided images, the presentation of the twins is crucial in determining the mode of delivery:

 

  • Image 1: Both twins are in a cephalic presentation (head down), making it safe to consider vaginal delivery. Twin pregnancies where both twins present cephalically are usually managed vaginally unless there are other contraindications.
  • Image 2: The first twin (Twin A or the lowermost baby) is in a breech presentation, while the second twin is cephalic. In this scenario, a cesarean section is preferred to avoid complications associated with breech delivery, such as cord prolapse or head entrapment. Therefore, cesarean delivery is the recommended mode for this presentation.

 

Indications for cesarean in twin pregnancy:

 

  1. First twin is non-cephalic (breech or transverse presentation).
  2. Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins: Elective LSCS at around 34 weeks.
  3. Conjoined twins.
  4. Higher-order multiples (triplets, quadruplets, or more).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In twin pregnancies, the mode of delivery is determined primarily by the presentation of the first twin. If the first twin is cephalic, vaginal delivery can be considered, but if the first twin is non-cephalic (e.g., breech), a cesarean section is generally recommended.

questions.text: A woman presents to OPD at 36 weeks of gestation and presents with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. On examination, fetal movements are normal, fetal parts not easily felt and muffled fetal heartbeat is heard. Symphysis fundal height came out to be 41 cm. Per abdomen examination reveals tense abdomen but not tender. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyhydramnios

 

The given scenario of 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

 

Polyhydramnios

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placenta: Abruption Placenta presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Hydrocephalus of fetus: Hydrocephalus of the fetus leads to increased head circumference in the fetus, which may cause an increased symphysis fundal height but unlikely to cause breathlessness and abdominal distension to this extent.

 

Option D. Fetal-maternal ascites: Patients of Fetal-maternal ascites commonly present with edema, proteinuria, hypertension, elevated liver enzymes and headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a 36 weeks pregnant woman with breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension and fundal height 41 cm, it most likely points to a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 46 XX

 

The scenario describes a patient with primary amenorrhea, secondary sexual characteristics, and a presence of the uterus and ovaries. The image shows an obstruction in the vaginal opening, which is likely an imperforate hymen. The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal internal reproductive organs, such as the uterus and ovaries, indicates that the chromosomal pattern is normal female, 46 XX. The karyotype is not affected by the physical obstruction causing the amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 45 XO: This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, where patients usually have streak ovaries, lack secondary sexual characteristics, and have other distinct features like webbed neck and short stature, none of which are present in this scenario.

 

Option C. 47 XXY: This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, typically found in males who present with hypogonadism, tall stature, and often gynecomastia. It is not applicable to the described scenario with a female presentation.

 

Option D. 46 XY: This karyotype is associated with male individuals or conditions like Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The presence of normal female internal reproductive structures (uterus and ovaries) rules out 46 XY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Functional ovarian cyst
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

 

Nulliparity is associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian tumors, including borderline ovarian tumors, possibly due to uninterrupted ovulation and hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Functional ovarian cyst: Functional ovarian cysts typically do not progress to ovarian tumors.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has not been strongly linked with increased risk of borderline ovarian tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

questions.text: A 16 weeks pregnant woman planned for Anomaly scan. Following the scan, the patient was advised to take a Quadruple test. Which is not part of the Quadruple test? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dimeric Inhibin B

 

The quadruple test is a second-trimester screening test performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy. The correct components of the quadruple test are:

 

  1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  2. Beta hCG
  3. Inhibin A (not B)
  4. Unconjugated estriol

 

In pregnancies with Down syndrome:

 

  • Beta hCG and Inhibin A levels are elevated
  • AFP and unconjugated estriol levels are decreased

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The quadruple test consists of four specific markers: AFP, beta hCG, Inhibin A (not B), and unconjugated estriol. Dimeric Inhibin B is not a component of this test.

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 wks
Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete.
Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks+5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy.

 

This pregnant woman is presenting with symptoms and signs of severe pre-eclampsia, which include:

 

  • Epigastric pain
  • Headache
  • Blurring of vision
  • Severe hypertension: Blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg.

 

In the context of severe pre-eclampsia at 35 weeks+5 days gestation, the management should include:

 

  • Treating hypertension: Immediate blood pressure control is crucial to prevent complications such as eclampsia, stroke, or placental abruption.
  • Administering magnesium sulfate (MgSO4): This is done to prevent eclamptic seizures.
  • Consideration for termination of pregnancy: In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks, the recommended course of action is to expedite delivery to prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management: Conservative management is not appropriate for severe pre-eclampsia due to the high risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option B. Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks: Tocolytics are contraindicated in severe pre-eclampsia as the goal is to deliver the baby as soon as the condition is stable, rather than delaying delivery.

 

Option C. Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete: As the patient is already beyond 34 weeks of gestation, steroid administration for fetal lung maturity is not necessary, and immediate delivery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe pre-eclampsia at or beyond 34 weeks of gestation, immediate management involves controlling hypertension, administering magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures, and expediting delivery.

 

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1850,  Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg267

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The patient's clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45XO), a condition characterized by:

 

  • Widely spaced nipples: Shield chest appearance.
  • Webbed neck: Due to congenital lymphedema.
  • Tanner grade 1 breast development: Indicates no breast development.
  • Streak ovaries on ultrasound: Ovaries that are underdeveloped and nonfunctional.
  • Hormonal profile: Raised FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries, and reduced estradiol indicating ovarian failure.

 

Other clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. The syndrome results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallmann syndrome: It is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), not hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46XY karyotype with female external genitalia, well-developed breasts, absent axillary and pubic hair, and gonads are testes, not streak ovaries.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Mullerian agenesis, where secondary sexual characters are present but the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina are absent. This syndrome does not present with webbed neck or widely spaced nipples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 441

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea. Laparoscopic finding is as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

The laparoscopic image shows an ovarian cyst filled with dark brown material, characteristic of a "chocolate cyst" or endometriotic cyst (endometrioma). Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside it, commonly on the ovaries, forming cysts filled with old blood. This is why they appear dark brown, resembling melted chocolate. The key symptom of endometriosis, as seen in this patient, is dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), which strongly supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, also known as mature cystic teratomas, contain various tissue types like hair, skin, and fat. They appear heterogeneous on imaging, often with calcifications, unlike the homogeneous blood-filled appearance of an endometriotic cyst.

 

Option C. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs, often presenting with pelvic pain, fever, and abnormal discharge. It does not typically result in cyst formation like what is seen in the image. PID usually shows inflamed and thickened structures rather than a distinct cystic mass.

 

Option D. Fibroid: Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus, usually solid and non-cystic in appearance. They do not present with blood-filled cysts on the ovaries as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, commonly forming chocolate cysts in the ovaries, which present as dark, blood-filled cysts on laparoscopic examination.

choices.text: Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse
Put the cord above the vertex

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is in labor. The cervix is 3 cm dilated and 70% effaced. A "bag of worms" is felt. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency LSCS

 

The description "bag of worms" suggests a cord prolapse, a critical situation where the umbilical cord precedes the fetus, risking compression. An emergency lower segment caesarean section (LSCS) is vital to prevent fetal distress or demise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture membranes and confirm cord prolapse: Rupturing membranes could worsen cord compression.

 

Option C. Put the cord above the vertex: Attempting to reposition the cord is risky and generally not recommended.

 

Option D. Wait for spontaneous delivery: Waiting is not advisable due to the risk of cord compression and fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected cord prolapse during labor, an emergency LSCS is the recommended course of action to safely deliver the baby and minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: G2 at 8 weeks diagnosed to have hyperthyroidism. What is the drug of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Propylthiouracil


Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is considered the safest option during this period because it minimizes the risk of congenital abnormalities. Methimazole and carbimazole are associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis, where infants are born with areas of missing skin. Iodine-131 is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to its radioactive nature, which can lead to fetal thyroid destruction and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Although methimazole is commonly used for hyperthyroidism, it is not recommended during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its association with fetal defects like aplasia cutis, where patches of skin are absent in the newborn.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Similar to methimazole, carbimazole is contraindicated in the first trimester due to the risk of fetal malformations, specifically aplasia cutis. It is often avoided in early pregnancy.

 

Option C. Iodine 131: This radioactive iodine treatment is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause severe fetal harm, including thyroid gland destruction and developmental issues, making it highly unsafe.

 

Educational Objective:


In the first trimester of pregnancy, propylthiouracil (PTU) is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism due to its safer profile compared to other antithyroid medications.
